commentBody:
The theme idea is fun, but the topmost themers came to me so quickly in the sea of Monday-level fill clues that I thought I would finish before I started. Luckily(?), finding more obscure themers and Tuesday-level fill clues as I went south made this fine (double) vision of Sunday wordplay something approaching a puzzle.

YMMV, of course, and frankly, I hope it did.
'Pro' is supposed to mean....pharmacist? Am I missing something??
Very breezy, perfect for a holiday weekend.
Lots of fun to solve! My favorite was probably SPAM SPAMALOT A LOT.
This was a good one. Mostly easy. Had Psalm for Paean for far too long. Lots of fun! Thanks!

Unhappy comments on a twisty Thursday?

CROSSCROSSWORDSWORDS

(Does not apply to fun Sundays!)

U of M alum here. Fun and clever premise. Too easy, though. The only place I even had to pause was the intersection of 118A and 109D. No idea on the latter. Eventually guessed on Mother of Perseus, which I should've known. Thanks for an entertaining jaunt, though, Victor and Tracy, and, of course, Go Blue!

[Potent potable for cunning actor Sylvester?]





SLYSTALLONETALLONE



Et tu, emu.
Fun theme. The section with NABOB and STILT crossing BILOBA and STREGA was tough for me.

Scot tells Bob the boss he can't...



NANABOBBOB



Noo, ma heids mince
I done did this puzz
For anyone who's interested: https://crosswordfiend.com/2025/04/19/sunday-april-20-2025/#ny
I‚Äôve been solving daily for many years now and this may be my new favorite set of theme entries!

After a relatively easy Thu, Fri and Sat this week, this was the perfect level of difficulty for a Sunday. Some slightly obscure trivia but I was surprised how things just fell into place when I wasn't expecting them to.

Victor and Tracy,

You HAD me at SPAMSPAMALOTALOT. 

(You almost lost me at the cross of ARC WELDS and WALE.)

Still, great fun. I had a WALE of a time!
Loved this. Funny and fun
Pretty easy, but a very fun theme.

"Isn't your plate of ham still under the weather?"
"No, it's cured."

(Sorry to Spam you with this one.)
Fun.

[Potent potable for cunning actor Sylvester?]





SLYSLYSTALLONETALLONE
i thought the theme was very contrived trying to be amusing. The cross of uracil // danae was impossible .

I enjoyed this but wish 

[Overlook a frosty patch?] NOT NOTICE ICE

[Funny scam at a nerdy San Diego event?] COMIC COMIC-CON CON

made the cut. Thanks, Tracy and Victor!

NABOB for Honcho is extremely tenuous clueing, especially for a word that's not part of most people's vocabulary, including mine.

I had to look it up, and the only similarities between the two is that they can both refer to a business leader, but that's not the primary definition of either term. Even within that definition, NABOB requires extreme wealth or status, while Honcho is simply someone who has people reporting to him in a managerial capacity.

Add to that the crossing of BILOBA and it ruins a perfectly good puzzle otherwise. Also, in close proximity STILT, which is not familiar to me, but I assume familiar to plenty, but there's no shortage of _A_S words that can hang (jaws, maws, caws, paws, yeah, I had swift instead of STILT)

Do lasers treat scars? Maybe they do; now I‚Äôm not certain. It sure took me some rebuilding around that section to find out that they treat ACNE. I had to remind myself again: Never plonk in a word you‚Äôre not 100% sure of, self, unless you have two‚ÄîTWO‚Äîcrosses in place. Otherwise it always ends badly. 

I appreciated SNORES sitting smack dab in the middle of the puzzle as I solved it with my person gingerly arranged around a snoring feline NABOB passed out smack dab in the middle of the bed. Se√±or Gato has found that a 10-lb body stretches so much better across roughly half a king-size bed in the absence of one of his people. Like the ASWAN dam across the Nile, come to think of it. My husband may have a hard time with cat REtrACTION ACTION when he gets home next week.

Happy Easter to ye Eastering folks, and a relaxing Sunday to everyone else.
But I don't like Spam!

I get all the theme answers except the pharmacist one. Is it a pro procures, or is a proporocure a thing?

I enjoyed the puzzle all in all, though.

Fun puzzle, but not overly difficult. If i know this group, there will be alot of appreciation for the SPAMALOT answer. Me, Iike Aaron Burr, I want to be in the room where it happened with MAD MADISON, Jefferson and Hamilton. https://youtu.be/zwfNRzCXsug?si=vIv3N2-jbPAnaE-V

I have been on quite a run this week. I got off to a good start tonight and quickly found the pattern. 

It was a wonderful puzzle with a lot of smiles along the way. I was thrilled to get the star on my last drop, the crossing for woodpecker food and fruit. I thought woodpeckers ate bugs and did not recognize the cross. Whew! No flyspecking.

As the first resident HEATHER to comment on today's puzzle, I want to thank all you little people who helped me realize my previously unknown dream of appearing in the New York Tmes crossword. It's truly an honor!  (Insert me bowing to roaring applause here.)

Also happy to have a drunken sailor and a Cuban dance crossing me. Sounds like a fun night!

This was really fun with all the themers - loved the word play - but it did go very fast for me. The lower part got a little bit trickier but I quickly knocked out the top themer at 25A and so that made the rest of them very achievable. Had some trouble at 62A crossing 67D... Didn't know the bird or the book title, but the long legs in the clue was a good hint.

SPAMSPAMSALOTALOT it's probably my favorite if I had to pick one, but I really enjoyed them all.

My last name hasn't been in the puzzle since 2021, but man that would have been something if it would have made it in. It's been in 20 times in the Shortz era, so the odds weren't nothing. But just imagine the big EGO I'd have about that! This is probably for the better. Instead I'll just go do the CHACHA!

TLDR: How very!  üòâ
Could not get into this puzzle.Had to look up too many of the trivia questions.

At the intersection of 3D and 65A I had and L for lAPS.  This made 3D POSTPOSTAlEAGE, which seemed kinda right, although I was confused by an E I didn't think I really needed.

I had several errors when I finished, and found two or three before I stumbled on this one, thinking about what would fit better than lAPS.  

I had just given up while I was literally on my way to the next check, when GAPS popped into my mind.

And it was even more satisfying that GAPS made POSTPOSTAGEAGE, getting rid of the nasty E.

And that was when I finally got the relief music.  "Relief" because it's really hard to go over and over a chunk of real estate that is the Sunday puzzle.
Little flap PETDOOR gave me a non-themed chuckle
Got stuck at the intersection of CENA and DANAE -- but, hey, Natick begins with an N, right?

I needed some 30 lookups for the trivia, and I found the theme extremely annoying - recently most Sunday themes have been dad-joke-level, cringey puns or wordplay, and this was no exception. I tried to enjoy the solve, anyway, but in the end I just revealed the 10% or so that was left. Meh.

I've never seen the words DRUPE and URACIL. They look very weird to me but maybe simply because they're unfamiliar. I checked whether I know the Polish counterparts. Nope. DRUPE is "pestkowiec" (literally "one with a pith"; the term is apparently only used by botanists and never comes up outside botanical science: I can't recall learning the word in 8 years of Biology classes), and URACIL is "uracyl": the word is as alien to me in my native tongue as it is in English.
Top-tier wordplay. Difficult solve requiring lookups but still a lot of fun. Extra points for the theme playing out both horizontally and vertically.

Don't refer to Silverstone film so much in crossword?

Deceit of an Indian footballer?

Foot ailment of an Italian born in January?

Thanks Tracy and Victor! 

This was a very enjoyable solve. I am surprised by all the negative comments as I thought the concept was refreshing and fun, and not too difficult. 

A lot of the complaints mention drupe, Danae and other words that have long been part of crosswordese. Commit them to memory because certainly you will see them again.

Great puzzle! The theme was very clever and cleanly executed. Eight themers! Whoopie! Nicely done. As many others have said, the top seemed maybe a little too easy, especially after parsing the theme entries, but the bottom was tough! 

Several things I didn't know, like the RNA base. Fun crosswordese, like NABOB. I think both Spiro Agnew and William Safire have achieved immortality for using that word so effectively. The clue for 56D lured me into thinking "well certainly this one will have Oreo in it!" Hah! I very much wanted a word like oof for Pound sound, thinking of the sound you get when you pound something. ARF was much better.
What a fantastic puzzle! So fun and silly, and the best part, it included a Whoopie Pie! Next to lobsters, a true Maine delicacy.

I tore through the top section feeling a little disappointed about how fast it was going. About halfway through I had to engage the part of my brain that was tied behind my back. The themers were less obvious, and the rest of the fill offered a little more resistance, making this a fun Sunday. Bonus points because I had the opportunity to use the theme to assist my solve. I always appreciate that. Extra, extra bonus points for The Cure: Friday I'M IN LOVE https://youtu.be/mGgMZpGYiy8?si=hCrFTgurFltgNHbM
Enjoyable puzzle!  (Although the crossing of ‚ÄúMother of Perseus‚Äù and ‚ÄúRNA base‚Äù was a little harsh).

WOWWOWSHOWHOW
it's done when a crossword  genius runs with a theme!
this is my favorite puzzle of all time as of today!
So varied, so rich, so sneaky in the best clever way!
I feel like I known this constructor's wide ranging eclectic  interests  intimately now that I finished after more than an hour and a half!
Today is Day 1,622 of my NYT crossword puzzle streak, and this puzzle is my all-time favorite.  Bravo!!

Man.  Our quirky language.  The things you can do with it!  I actually did a double take when I saw what was going on in the theme answers.  I am still childlike when presented with wordplay like this, and there I was, with my jaw dropped and thinking, ‚ÄúThis is amazing!‚Äù

So, I rode though this outing with an inner smile.  A trio of memorable moments:
‚Ä¢	Shook my head at how quickly I had forgotten PPE, the term that was everywhere during covid.
‚Ä¢	[Liver spot] for ABODE was so silly I immediately fell in love with it.
‚Ä¢	DEMAGOG won me over because it contains Biblical pair Gog and Magog.

Eight long theme answers for a Sunday puzzle is impressive.  One thing that helped the constructors do it was the addition of an extra column.

Thank you, Victor and Tracy, for finding this quirk in our language and flying with it.  What fun ‚Äì this was a hoot!
Cute puzzle and very enjoyable, thanks :-). I only got caught up in one letter regarding RNA and Perseus.   Almost a gold star pour moi, Merci!  :)

[Check the fine print?]


REREADAD

A fun one.

Uttered a CROSS CROSSWORD WORD at the cross of DANAE and URACIL. Never CENA word like that.

Theme revealed itself early in my solve, twas fun.


Happy Easter, 420 day, last day of Passover, National Look-Alike Day, Chinese Language Day, National Mail Order Catalog Day, Serendipity Day, International Orangutan Day, National Cheddar Fries Day, Pizza Delivery Driver Appreciation Day ‚Ä¶ yada yada.

Strands!
No spoilers, plz, we're on the hunt.

Strands #413
‚ÄúOn the hunt‚Äù
üü°üîµüîµüîµ
üîµüîµüîµüîµ

Oh, come on!

How can *anyone* resist
crossword puzzling when gems like 
this baby are out there?

How?

SPAMS SPAMALOT A LOT?
WHOO WHOOPIE PIE?

That‚Äôs just word-joy.

P.S.
I am kind of sad that the answer to 56D wasn‚Äôt what I first imagined it was going to be:

WHOOPIE WHOOPIE-PIE PIE

but that would have been ‚Äúyay! a large sandwich-cookie tart!‚Äù
anyone else have "ODES" for 79 down? sorta works too

It makes me happy to see that so many people loved this puzzle. For me, many of the clues were too far a stretch to be fun. Fan mail isn‚Äôt SPAM, no matter how much of it you get. WOOD SCREW does not indicate hanging wall art. I just don‚Äôt vibe with these meanings of AGOG and NABOB. Bleh. Anyway, onward.

I discovered the theme very quickly (I thought) as the NW-quadrant was solving rather easily.  When I got POST POST, I thought to myself, "Oh, I see.  Very clever." And I thought it would conclude POST POSTAl time, or something similar.

When I saw the duplication with AGE, at first I thought it didn't make sense.  And then the penny dropped, and I thought "Brilliant!"

None of the other themed answers topped this one for me (although I did enjoy hearing about MAD MADISON), but the verdict is still "Brilliant!"
Anyone not familiar with the story of how Dana√´ gave birth to Perseus should look it up! Those Greeks could tell a wild story! https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dana%C3%AB
Very solid Sunday. Congrats Victor and Tracy!
Doesn't the grid look like a huge bunny with a basket, or am I just stoned?

It took me 2 hours and 46 minutes, but I finally got it with no look ups.  What held me up was 85 Across. Can someone please explain this one to me DEMDEMAGOAGOG.  What in the world does this hjave to do with eagerness to hear?  Also, the correct spelling is DEMAGOUGUE.  This is an example of a bad clue -  a very bad clue. I'm surprised Will Shortz allowed it.

This one took me a long time, nearly an hour and a half, that's because I had to go round and round with crossing letters, which were very helpful, and had to look up the actors and singers.

Apart from the Spam clue (of course) it took me a while to get the long clues, which then didn't mean a lot to me!

It didn't occur to me that Tiger referred to a person, even with WOOD! (only found out reading Wordplay) I was so sure it was about a painting of a tiger (like Henri Rousseau's) but I did solve most, eventually. 

Portfolio - I could only think of art college and paintings.

Heather is fairly popular in Scotland, along with Fiona and Isla (Eye-la, like the island or the malt whisky).

RTS? I can only find Return To Sport.

Not bad though, despite culture clash.
This was an absolute delight. A masterpiece and a delight. Thank you!

It sure has been nice to no longer pad my comments just to make them long enough to sneak past the emus.  I had complained about this more than once to the NYT, as I suppose others did as well, and am so very happy (and surprised) that they actually did something about it.  Thank you to whomever on the NYT staff championed this cause to make it become a reality.

When James Monroe angrily mutes a political commercial...

MAD MADISON AD IS ON

But the original answer was fine, as were all the themers, but I did try to work Bernie into 85A. And then there's SHANTY vs chant(e)y. Why not just clue it as an island hut?

(Must not hate on the Michiganders, because it's Easter, but Go Buckeyes!)
I loved this puzzle today and the Monday from this month by the same author! thanks!!
First rate.
Appreciated, but not enjoyed.

The title did a lot to point me in the right direction, and once I saw how the theme worked, I could put in a lot of theme answers' letters in place, based on the ones I already had.  This made the puzzle easier than normal.

Since I was watching the end of the Mets game as I was doing it last night, I didn't have a remarkable time, but I found the puzzle easy to complete, thanks to the nature of the theme.

Neat idea. I definitely wondered if I was seeing double.

Here's my contribution:

"Swindler mischaracterizing his misdeeds in court?"

CONCONTORTSTORTS

Interesting solving week by the way. My solves, from fastest to slowest:

Mon Thu Sat Tue Fri Wed

Other than Monday, the solves were within four minutes of each other time-wise.

Awesome Easter egg at 47A!

Well done! 

/decloak

Thought it was interesting how many folks view one of the building blocks of life (URACIL) as "trivia" but kick themselves when they can't remember a character out of ancient Greek mythology (DANAE). Fun puzzle; while I got the theme fairly early on it was still a nice challenge to piece the answers together. Thanks Victor and Tracy!

Hard to compose no doubt, but unfair to solvers, which is no fun. The Tiger clue does serve to alert solvers to the clever wordplay, but why does ‚Äúwall art‚Äù point to wood and screws? It doesn‚Äôt. The Times cuts this puzzle too much slack between clues and answers.

And laboring over such obscure clues/answers (‚Äúdrupe‚Äù? ‚ÄúMadison is on‚Äù etc etc) is worse in the enlarged Sunday format.
As an editor, my favorite theme answer was RED REDACTION ACTION. Everyone fears the red pen! (But not emus!)

Often the theme in these puzzles is either redundant and only noticed after solving, or an irritating impediment to solving. This was neither, perfectly tricky-but-gettable and fun to work out during the solve.
There were a couple of slightly dodgy filler words and clues for me, but in the end one of the best Sundays I've done for a while - thanks Victor and Tracy!

Well, it takes a lot of different critters to make these fritters, and no matter how much OIL or TOMATO you toss in the fire, just might not be to taste.

Hat's off for all the work this mammoth took to tame - on to Monday, and a very Happy Sunday to all!

Got through that without lookups, but only just. 
The cross at STREG_ and _SADA was a dither between A and O, but the A seemed the likely choice, just for agreement with "Nona".
The Italian restaurant stood at S_A_RO until the end, with the missing letters being something to do with offensive linesmen, and some sort of scan that looked thoroughly unmedical. B seemed like the only plausible letter to complete _IOSCAN, and R completed RTS, only because it was a plausible fit with Italian orthography.
Was a little surprised to get my gold star at that point.

The theme was OK, and certainly made the solve easier. I'm not a fan of laboured puns, and have no idea what WHOOWHOOPIEPIE might signify, but once I got the idea of the repeated pattern it was certainly a big help.
I loved the puzzle! But can someone explain 32A to me? How does a WALE relate to Corduroy? Have I pickled my brain with too many Easter candies?

If anyone is looking for another puzzle for today, I enjoyed Evan Birnholz‚Äôs WaPo puzzle, ‚ÄúAssumed Names.‚Äù There‚Äôs a thematic element to it that won‚Äôt appeal to everyone, but the wordplay is a lot of fun.
yeah, boo. inane is right.

I remember when I was very young my parents gave me for Christmas a pair of corduroys. 

I spent a Child‚Äôs Christmas in WALES.
Wonderful! Reminds me of the hilarious 30 Rock joke when Angie says ‚ÄúMy album ‚Äòmy album is dropping‚Äô is dropping‚Äù

Yankees vs. Rays Game Highlights (4/19/25)


DOUBLE DOUBLE PLAY PLAY

It must have been quite the challenge to construct those double entendres. Hats off!

It was also an overall pleasant solve that put up a bit of a fight. 

I don‚Äôt think I‚Äôve ever seen DEMAGOG spelled without a ‚Äúue‚Äù on the end. Must be an American thing.

Spent hours on it. Just couldn't quit. But when I finally had it all filled in, I got the "at least one" notice. I looked and looked, but then took advantage of being a subscriber ("t[ook] a peek at the answer key) and found my error to be, after all, the T I had at the 69A/D crossing. I now have my first seven-day phony streak in years. I don't think I'll try that again. It's time to make lunch and I haven't got to Spelling Bee, Wordle, Waffle, email, and my Sunday morning paper yet!

inquiring minds would like to hear from those who attended the recent crossword tournament, especially first-time competitors. Did anyone place? Too modest to brag?
I've already shared how humbling my own experience was, so how much worse could anyone else's be?

Good puzzle IMHO. I was utterly defeated by 104A because I was so sure of "chanty". Nope; turns out there are MANY variant spellings.
So I "took a peek at the answer" and got THAT fixed. I had confidently deleted the dowloaded pdf (phone has been griping about storage lately). So then when STILL no happy music I was too embarrassed to download it again. Anyway my phone has decided that Minivan is the default app for pdfs. (For those of you not into political door-knocking, that's the app that gives you the list of addresses with voter names plus mapping help and lets you record responses.)
  Luckily I did realize 3D was wrong; had POSTAL not POSTAGE and had ignored that the ending made no sense (somehow LAPS did????)
Slightly under my (unimpressive) Sunday average but definitely not too easy.

Hi Victor! Hi Tracy! Fun puzzle--I'll be in A2 on Tuesday!

No 19 from *Fifty-one Tales*:

THE DEMAGOGUE AND THE DEMI-MONDE

A demagogue and a demi-mondaine chanced to arrive together at the gate of Paradise. And the Saint looked sorrowfully at them both.

"Why were you a demagogue?" he said to the first.

"Because," said the demagogue, "I stood for those principles that have made us what we are and have endeared our Party to the great heart of the people. In a word I stood unflinchingly on the plank of popular representation."

"And you?" said the Saint to her of the demi-monde.

"I wanted money," said the demi-mondaine.

And after some moments' thought the Saint said: "Well, come in; though you don't deserve to."

But to the demagogue he said: "We genuinely regret that the limited space at our disposal and our unfortunate lack of interest in those Questions that you have gone so far to inculcate and have so ably upheld in the past, prevent us from giving you the support for which you seek."

And he shut the golden door.

--Edward John Moreton Drax Plunkett, 18th Baron Dunsany
Loved the Q's in the mini today!  Very clever.

My usual late puzzle finds. I'll re-post these tomorrow. Two Sunday puzzles by Bette Sue Cohen with somewhat similar themes. Just the basic trick in the clues was different in the two puzzles. Some examples from the first one - from January 23, 1983. "Kubrick code word?" STANLEYBAKER "Cantrell gymnast?" LANATURNER "Segal seethes?" GEORGEBURNS "Ratoff measure?" GREGORYPECK "Taylor pile at Las Vegas?" ROBERTSTACK And there were several more. Don't think I would have much a chance at that one. Here's the Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/PS?date=1/23/1983&g=116&d=A I'll put the other puzzle in a reply. ...

Haven‚Äôt enjoyed a Sunday puzzle this much in a while.  I was smiling the whole time while rushing to the next clue. Not because I was timing myself, but because I couldn‚Äôt wait to see what it was.  
Great fun - thanks constructors!!
what a beauty of a puzzle its ingenious thanks!

Was very excited with how quickly I was going through the first half of this puzzle. I got the theme right away and was cooking. Then the bottom half of the puzzle let me know, there would not be a personal best in my future today. I muddled through and eked out an average time. Fun puzzle.
Wow! Absolutely brilliant.
Loved this puzzle. GO BLUE!
Fantastic puzzle! Fun and charming with just enough spice. Also, GO BLUE!!
Thanks for a very fun, Sunday, Victor! A great theme that I finally figured out about halfway through. Looking forward to seeing more in the future!

I have been doing crossword puzzles for long enough to know that the constructors/editors live in some cave where they are not exposed to what is happening in normal society, but given what is going on in the world right now I did not find the liberal-dem-demagog pun funny. The puns are supposed to be funny.

Too late to write much. Solved this unaided, but wasn't sure at the WALE/ARCWELDS crossing. Guessed right, eschewing ARCMELDS. Knew DANAE, and URACIL made sense.

Very clever, and most of the themers were pretty solid, though rather silly too.

Enjoyed this one.
Lost my connections streak because at least one guess that should have said I was one off didn't say anything, which meant I abandoned good paths. Disappointing:(
One of the cleverer schemes I've encountered here, but once you get a few crossing squares filled in, the pattern of the theme actually helped fill the rest in until I got the wordplay being sought.

Just my little peeves:

URACIL/DANAE and PAEAN/ASWAN are a little obnoxious as crosses. You either know them or you don't which is OK for a Saturday but a little nasty for a Sunday. One would be OK because you could play the vowel game but two...

SPARing earned me two concussions and some broken ribs, the latter courtesy of a Marine visiting our class who had learned in one of the martial arts schools in Okinawa that emphasize very hard, robot-like kicks and punches...like a fool, I tried to jam one of his kicks. I still have a very visible dent in my ribcage.

And of course the usual assortment of black eyes and split lips.

So maybe not so playful.
Some niche, tricky clues, overall very clever and satisfying to finish!
best puzzle in years.  great clues.

Love the shout out to Heathie! Good puzzle. I appreciate all the word play but as an ASIDE am hard-pressed to think of a hotheaded  liberal demagogue, although I think we could certainly use one. You might say Corey Booker, Bernie Sanders or AOC but they aren‚Äôt illogical or lying. Demagogues are usually purely rhetorical and try to stir up emotions often with little regard for safety(Sarah Palin) or the facts(One very famous faux populist is coming to mind/Oh, it‚Äôs just on the tip of my tongue)! But it‚Äôs not like this is a very important time to get this right, is it? :/
Always happy to see my own identity, ARO, in a solve! I suspect the NYT agrees with me. We love nothing more than three of the most common letters in the alphabet :)
Props to the constructor! This one took me awhile, but the theme was amazing--especially since it was in the verticals too. Very impressive and a crunchy one for me.
This is truly one of the best most clever and creative puzzles I've ever seen. It was also a great deal of fun. Thank you.
I like that your editors are out and about, finding new constructors. Sometimes they find them in the same town!

Anyone else know NABOB from Aladdin? 

"I'm on the job you big nabob, you ain't never had a friend like me"
LOVED today's theme. As a newer puzzler (just hit my first 30 day streak!), Sundays are always difficult for me. The fun theme made it so much more enjoyable! Thank you, Victor and Tracy!

Totally agree with what the columnist wrote here! Solving this puzzle scratched an itch in my brain. I loved solving it and wanted more. As someone who usually struggles with the Sunday, I surprisingly kind of flew through this one!! Not too much obscurity, didn‚Äôt need to know a ton of pop culture or sports, no odd language translations. Straight up fun!!!
If the clue would have been 'Ball and Stick formation' then RNA a snap.
Another awful disappointment.

114D Hanker (for)
Please would someone explain JONES? 
TY

@Barry Ancona

I too zipped through the top part and found the bottom part a bit more challenging.

@Ben Blackwell
Pharmacists are PROs when it comes to procuring cures.

@Ben Blackwell well pro is short for professional.

I guess because they are a professional who distributes drugs‚Ä¶as opposed to good time Charlie who was at your last party.
@Cat Lady Margaret Omg this was the entry that sparked the theme in my head originally!!!
@Victo, haha, thanks for sharing that!

@Cat Lady Margaret
Could also clue that as:
Puzzlers prepare to duel?
CROSS CROSSWORD SWORDS
@Lewis -- Argh!  I rushed this.  I shall post the correct answer in a bit!  I am sorry!

(second try)

Oh dear, I rushed this, and the answer isn't correct.  Ignore this post please!  I shall post the correct answer shortly...
@Curt Yeah, that section cost me my gold star

Francis,

Eddie reported an undone puzz this week...

Francis,

He‚Äôs got fans, and as of yesterday, detractors.
This thing is headed for greatness!

@Francis
As a former Kentuckian who just got back from a visit, I feel committed to finding out every day whether Eddie done did the puzz or if the puzz was too hard.

@Eddie 
Go Eddie go!

Eric,

I think we did the same puzzle!

@Barry Ancona

I just read your comment. Yep, it sounds like we had much the same experience.

@Eric Hougland

Thanks for the article. Like you, I also found that recognizing the pattern early on helped me with other answers in the puzzle. 

I think I learned NABOB from the Spelling Bee. 

A couple of nits:

I think there's a misplaced apostrophe in WOODS‚Äô WOODSCREW CREW. Maybe I'm wrong about this, but since Woods is his name and not a plural, wouldn't it be WOODS's WOODSCREW CREW? But adding an extra s breaks the pattern, so I think it's just WOODS WOODSCREW CREW. 

In the SPAMALOT one there's an extra S. SPAMS SPAMALOT A LOT should be SPAM SPAMALOT A LOT.

@Beth I think the apostrophe belongs there. I was taught that if you want to pronounce two Ss in the possessive, you should add 's to the name. So Woods's would be pronounced woodzes. But the pronunciation is debatable, and therein lies the conflict. I think I would say, about a golf club, "that's Woods' wood" or about said golfer's screw "that's Woods' wood screw." You might think that's just absurd, no sane person would ever say that. ;) Luckily the language has room for both of us.

@Mean Old Lady

@Robco

Both RNA and DNA have four bases; URACIL is the only one found in RNA and not DNA.

DNA consists of adenine (A), cytosine (C), guanine (G), and thymine (T), while RNA consists of adenine (A), guanine (G), cytosine (C), and uracil (U).

At least in New York State, this is taught in high school biology.  The fact that the clue focused on RNA made the answer obvious to non-science major me.

As for DANAE, I recognized it as a name from mythology, but did not know the details.

Francis,

Crossing words from different fields should make the cross letter more accessible to more solvers.

@HeathieJ

I had to go back and reread your first couple of lines before I realized Heathie is a nickname for Heather.

I'm terrible with nicknames.  A lot of them make no sense at all to me, like Peg for Margaret, or Jack for John, or Bob for Robert.

Yours is one of the somewhat rare name/nickname pair that the nickname is no shorter than the original.  Like Jack for John.

I'm sure now that I've brought it up, most of you will come up with a half dozen examples in your first ten seconds of thinking about it.

@Andrzej

Dick/Richard is another great example of our baffling nicknames.

@Francis

A traditional Polish nickname for Andrzej is Jƒôdrek (and its diminutive: Jƒôdru≈õ) - also quite baffling. Usually Polish nicknames (unlike Russian ones: Sasha for Alexander?) stick to the first letters of the original name: Katarzyna/Kasia, Bart≈Çomiej/Bartek, W≈Çadys≈Çaw/W≈Çadek, Genowefa/Genia. Some don't though, like Andrzej/Jƒôdrek but also Jakub/Kuba.

@Andrzej @Francis

In my youth, and still with the many dear friends that I am blessed to still have from my youth, I'm known as Heath. 

One very wild and crazy old friend used to call me Heathmo! 

With a certain group of people from my former long time work and still present happy hour friends, I'm known as HJ, which, I later came to understand from the youngest people in that group is its own, umm, questionable abbreviation. 

But my dear husband has long referred to me affectionately as Heathie...   thus most of his family does too. So that is what I went with out here. At this point of my life, I feel like it captures me better than any of the others.

And.... I have never, ever, understood why any Richard wants to go by Dick. I had an uncle nicknamed Dick, and from as soon as I understood the other meeting of that, I could not understand why he went by that nickname. I suppose it was different when he was younger.

I also knew a dear Alexander known as Sasha, who was from Russia and the father of a very dear friend, who frequently called me Oh Captain, My Captain.  

What's in a name, anyhow!? ‚ò∫Ô∏è

@Francis

I do know about Jack. I read many years  ago that It apparently comes from the French, something like Jeanquin, meaning little John. Over time the pronunciation slid toward Jacques or Jack.*

With Peg/Margaret I can't help you though, and my mother was a Peg.

*But that was then. Today the Wikipedialists may well correct me about this.

@Teresa
And now I have a Steely Dan earworm.

@Andrzej

There's a Colorado rep who goes by the name Dusty Johnson.  Cracks me up every time I hear it.  Why would someone do that?
@HeathieJ I had the almost unbelievable pleasure a few years ago of having my first name AND my husband‚Äôs first name appear in the puzzle one day. I know how fun that is!

@Nancy J.

I would guess that Dusty came up as a nickname back in the wild west cattle ranching days. Spending days on the trail, guiding the cattle to market, you're going to eat a lot of dust, and it's going to be all over you and your clothes, hence the descriptive nickname. Unusual, because it's more of a job-derived one that anything related to one's actual name.

@HeathieJ

Note to self: HEAT HEATHER HER celebratory whoopie Pie.

@Andrzej

Nicknames and euphemisms and slang are all quite fascinating.  Sometimes you can "puzzle out" the changes that have been made over time, but often the transitions are lost in the haze of lore.

Nicknames/euphemisms/slang for so-called "private parts" are even more fascinating.  There are so many!  And so many jump form one language to another.  (I'm thinking of Yiddish slang now. Oy!)  
I've often wondered how one could go through life with a name like Dick Johnson.  Or how about "Groundskeeper Willie"?  I guess it's a case of "If it's yours, own it!"

@The X-Phile

Ummm, feathie ü´§)   is that my middle name is Lee, so in younger days, some would say that I'm looking very Heatherly today, or some such. So, Heathie sort of connects me to that, minus the erl.

@HeathieJ

You‚Äôre welcome. 

I‚Äôm glad you like your name. When I think of the Heathers I I‚Äôve known (relatively few), I think of the office manager where I worked. She was very good at her job. @HeathieJ Just weighing in as another Heather. @Andrzej

Yeah, I thought of you when I wrote that--I thought of one of your posts in which you'd given up on looking for errors on Sunday.

I think I eventually will, too, on Sundays.  

For one thing solving a puzzle is a blast, but looking for an error is like the dentist poking around in your teeth looking for sensitive spots.  

Here's an entrepreneurial idea for someone--design some mechanism to make searching for the errors less painful, but with as little change to the current levels of "cheating" that we now hold in our minds.

When I first started, it irritated me when I got the "Not done" screen because it didn't tell me *how many* squares were wrong.  Is there some wriggle room there?

@Lewis PPE was such a common abbreviation during the Covid era, and I can only remember it being used in that context. This clue made me wonder if it's commonly used outside of a pandemic. Do construction workers refer to hard hats as PPE? ü§î

@OboeSteph

At the moment, I walk past a construction site almost every day. At the gate, there's a big sign reading: PPE MUST BE WORN BEYOND THIS POINT.

@OboeSteph

In the medical field it's very common, especially when dealing with communicable diseases, potential blood or chemical (drug) exposure, or immune-related issues.

In the dialysis world, we wore face masks, face/eye shields, sometimes splash-proof gowns as well as nitrile gloves; and it was even worse if we had to worry about patients in isolation because of infections or lack of immunity. PPE saved my butt at least a couple of times.

Other areas had differing levels of PPE required.

@Lori Taum It's an expression that's been around since the 1960s, originally coined to talk about heroin withdrawal. It's become commonplace to use as a craving for practically anything. "I'm really jonesing for a cheesesteak right now."

@Brandon
TYVM ! Appreciate the explanation. Jones in that context  was new to me
After I read your response, I googled JONES & found this:

jones ljonz | US informal
noun a fixation on or compulsive desire for someone or something, typically a drug; an addiction: a two-year amphetamine jones.
verb [no object] (jones on/for) have a fixation on; be addicted to: Palmer was jonesing for some coke again.
ORIGIN
1960s: said to come from Jones Alley, in Manhattan, associated with drug addicts.
